key_points: Jurors from Derek Chauvin's trial speak out for the first time, describing the trial as life-altering and haunting.
They based their verdict on evidence presented during the trial, not their views on race.
Video evidence, especially the footage of Chauvin kneeling on Floyd's neck, played a significant role in their deliberation.
Jurors sought to ensure due diligence was done in their deliberations, with no room for error.
Some jurors received counseling and therapy due to the emotional toll of the trial.
The jury deliberated for over 10 hours across two days before reaching a unanimous verdict.
Despite widespread protests framing the incident within systemic racism, jurors insist race did not influence their deliberations.
Bystander videos were crucial in capturing the events leading to George Floyd's death.
Jurors found watching the video of Floyd's death repeatedly to be emotionally taxing.
The jurors feel an ongoing emotional impact from their experience, with some no longer wanting to see the video of Floyd's death.
